item.title: Carl Zimmer
item.description: Early next year, I'll be talking about my new book, AIR-BORNE. On publication day, February 25, I'll be in New York for an on-stage conversation with Jad Abumrad, creator of Radiolab, at 92NY. Join us, good people of New York! Details here https://www.92ny.org/event/the-life-we-breathe 1/4

item.title: Carl Zimmer
item.description: I’ll also be talking in Boston, New Haven, St. Louis, and other places. I’m keeping a running list of events on my website: https://carlzimmer.com/talks/ 2/4

item.title: Carl Zimmer
item.description: In my latest email newsletter, I explain how working with Jad on a Radiolab episode at the start of the pandemic helped hurl me into the remarkable world of aerobiology, which led to my writing a book about the experience. https://buttondown.com/carlzimmer/archive/fridays-elk-the-air-borne-tour-takes-shape/ 3/4

item.title: Cory Doctorow
item.description: Back in 2018, around the time I emailed my immigration lawyer about applying for US citizenship, I started work on a short story called "Radicalized," which eventually became the title story of a collection that came out in 2019:https://us.macmillan.com/books/9781250228598/radicalized/--If you'd like an essay-formatted version of this thread to read or share, here's a link to it on pluralistic.net, my surveillance-free, ad-free, tracker-free blog:https://pluralistic.net/2024/12/09/radicalized/#deny-defend-depose1/

item.title: Spencer LaVere Smith
item.description: What would you change about academia life?There’s a discussion on bsky about saying “no” to service requests. But really, why is it even such an issue? A healthy institution or community should be able to spread the load. This is a strange job.
